title: Instagram
description: Instagram posts for nytcooking, sohlae, swissmiss, soulfirefarm.

items.title: The Mohican Nation: "People of the waters that are‚Ä¶
items.content_html:
@soulfirefarm

The Mohican Nation: "People of the waters that are never still." Sharing our stories, people to people, is such an important part of sovereignty work. Heather Bruegl from the Mohican nation presented to our team about the history and legacy of the Stockbridge Munsee Mohican people. As people not indigenous to the land we inhabit, it has been integral that we explore the ways we can be accountable to the land‚Äôs original stewards. Part of our relationship building process has been establishing a cultural respect easement that gives Mohican citizens the legal right to use Soul Fire land for ceremony and wildcrafting whenever they please in perpetuity. As in years past, all proceeds of our seed sales are remitted to the Mohican nation for their cultural work. We remain committed to ongoing solidarity with and accountability to the Mohican community. If you know anyone from the Mohican Nation, check out the flyer in the images - help them share their stories! Also pictured are beautiful ears of Mohican corn. The corn was planted in the Stockbridge-Munsee Mohican style, as requested by Warren Mihtukwsun, "The corn is planted in mounds. The mounds are about 32" wide and 2 ft. tall. The Sturgeon and sucker run is always in the Spring. In the Spring we spear the suckers and put them in the mounds. This might be hard to replicate, but chicken bones, eggshells and/or compost could be put in the mounds if desired. Plant 12-13 corn seeds per mound, starting at the bottom of the mound and planting each seed "from pinkie to thumb distance" apart. If desired, plant beans "around the outskirts of the mound" at the same time as the corn. Some mounds could have sunflowers planted on them instead of corn." We are saving this seed and sharing with our Stockbridge Munsee Mohican friends in Wisconsin.

items.content_html:
@soulfirefarm

Catch Naima speaking with other engaged leaders about necessary steps we can take now to realize a thriving community that is welcoming to all.¬† The Chamber's Diversity, Equity & Inclusion Collaborative is proud to present ‚ÄúTogether We Face Racial Injustice‚Äù the 2021 Diversity, Equity and Inclusion (DEI) Summit! March 10 from 12:00 PM to 1:00 PM EST. Head to the link in our bio to sign up! @naimainfinity

items.title: Each One, Teach One
items.content_html:
@soulfirefarm

Each One, Teach One. Many Hands Make Light Work. Volunteer with us at Soul Fire Farm to learn about some of our farming practices while supporting our work and getting your hands on the land. During our first Work and Learn Days (April 1st, April 6th, April 8th, April 13th) participants will collaborate with Soul Fire team members on mulching beds, planting lowbush blueberries, planting trees, and spreading compost. Registration required. IMPORTANT: Due to the pandemic we are limiting work-and-learn days to those residing in New York State or bordering states of NJ, CT, PA, MA & VT. If you are not coming from these states we kindly ask you participate in a virtual program instead. See all of our programs by visiting the link in our bio! Please only register if you are able to stay for the entire day as spots are limited. Given the decreased capacity of our programs during COVID, we ask that you kindly limit your registration to ONE community farm day. Your consideration and generosity ensures accessibility to this healing time on the land to as many people as possible! Check out some pics from last year‚Äôs mulching and compost spreading days! Head to the link in our bio to register!

items.title: Visioning Abundance: Crop Planning for Resilience
items.content_html:
@soulfirefarm

Visioning Abundance: Crop Planning for Resilience. Virtual Bilingual Skill-share 3/11, 3-4:30 pm ET.¬† If you haven‚Äôt registered yet for our first 3D of 2021, you still have time! Head to the link in our bio to register by noon on 3/10! We are kicking off this year‚Äôs 3D Virtual Skill-share series with a visionary workshop guided by SFF Co-Director Larisa Jacobson and Rock Steady Farmer (@rocksteadyfarm ) Amara Ullari (@mishi_amara)¬† We are invoking the quiet and stillness that the winter offers to guide us in reflection, dreaming, and planning for how our upcoming growing season will flourish. This visionary practice is what we call crop planning, a process that paints a big picture idea of what we will be growing over the season and then breaks it down to the details of how we will achieve our goals to ensure an abundant season.¬† This interactive virtual skill share is designed for BIPOC and features Spanish interpretation. Amara (@mishi_amara) also shares their Crop Planning brilliance in our forthcoming Liberation on Land Video coming soon! Available free for everyone.

items.title: We see the light
items.content_html:
@soulfirefarm

We see the light!!! An exciting moment in the classroom build, illuminating the space that holds layers of intention for holding our community and honoring the Earth. And we see the light at the end of the tunnel! With the final coats of plasters near completion, we are installing interior and exterior doors, as well as finishing the ventilation system. This was designed in the early stages of covid to adapt to the needs of being healthy indoors together. We now see that this decision was a good one that will help us keep people as safe as possible. We also have been installing lighting fixtures (which we think look FIRE!), and are preparing to install local hardwood floors. The construction team is also enduring late winter storms and harsh temperatures to install the exterior siding. What lies underneath is a thoughtful design that creates a robust durable finish, keeping the building dry and ventilated for decades to come. We think of every building project as a metaphor for our relationships: there is so much we cannot see below the surface. We just need time, patience and curiosity to learn.

items.title: The sap rises in the maple trees and the streams s‚Ä¶
items.content_html:
@soulfirefarm

The sap rises in the maple trees and the streams start to flow under the snow pack. For the farmers, this is greenhouse seeding time. We tuck dormant packets of genetic possibility into moist potting soil and wait for onions, cilantro, parsley, lettuce and other ‚Äúcold crops‚Äù to germinate. We pay homage to our ancestors for their innovation in these greenhouse technologies. We give thanks to the 1000+ enslaved African people on the Wye Plantation, including Frederick Douglass, who built, engineered, and operated an impressive greenhouse in 1775 that still stands. They buried their protective amulets at the entrance, hid their sacred thunderstones in the roof, cultivated hundreds of culinary and medicinal plants, and held celebrations with song and dance in the space. Shout out to Farmer Tiffany LaShae (@tiffanielou) for teaching us this history during a 3D skillshare. Check out our LOL Video to learn more about greenhouse propagation by checking out the link in our bio! And don‚Äôt miss the next Soul Fire 3D Skill Share this Thursday on Crop Planning!

items.title: The abundance of food and medicine either grown by‚Ä¶
items.content_html:
@soulfirefarm

The abundance of food and medicine either grown by your own hand or those that are birthed effortlessly by the land extends far beyond the growing season. Leah was able to restock our shop with soothing, luxurious salves! Salves are simple to make, completely plant-based, and nourishing. Homemade medicines are infused not only with the magic of the Earth, but also with love and the intention of healing and relief. Our shop is stocked with two different salves that promote different types of healing. We have our Soothing Salve that is a healing body butter containing olive oil, Soul Fire beeswax, calendula, comfrey, and peppermint. This salve helps relieve insect bites, diaper rash, dryness, scrapes, and minor irritation. It‚Äôs the perfect salve for summertime when the mosquitos come out. We also have a White Pine Salve that contains olive oil, Soul Fire beeswax, and wildcrafted white pine needles and resin from the sacred land that Soul Fire Farm sits on. This salve has antiseptic, antifungal, and antibacterial properties making it highly effective in treating eczema, psoriasis, rashes and other skin irritations. Head to the link in our bio to purchase and take a look at the other items in our shop.

items.title: "I created this painting to honor our visionary fo‚Ä¶
items.content_html:
@soulfirefarm

"I created this painting to honor our visionary foremothers who braided seeds of prophecy into fertile crowns, as an act of resilience in the face of the most horrifying journey imaginable. I represented the black-eyed pea because it is a sacred food indigenous to Africa that is staple throughout the diaspora and shows up in so many beloved dishes (akra pwa, acaraje, hoppin' john...) and is a symbol of prosperity, blessings, and fertility. Also black-eyed peas are legumes that build soil health, like alchemists taking nitrogen from the air and giving it back to the earth, a method popularized by George Washington Carver, who was born into slavery and overcame unthinkable obstacles to become a pioneering agricultural scientist.‚Äù ~ Naima Penniman @naimainfinity What are the barriers in your life that feel impossible to push past? What are the oppressions that seem so entrenched in the fabric of our society? What are the seeds we can smuggle in the face of that, that might find a future on fertile ground? You can purchase a 11"x17" print of Naima‚Äôs dedication painting for "Farming While Black" by Leah Penniman. Available on our online store for $15. Head to the link in our bio. Text reads: "We are descendants of futurists, carrying on the legacy of our ancestral grandmothers, who braided seeds in their hair before boarding transatlantic slave ships, believing against odds in a future of sovereignty on land."

items.title: On March 25th, Emporia University presents a keyno‚Ä¶
items.content_html:
@soulfirefarm

On March 25th, Emporia University presents a keynote address delivered by Soul Fire Farm‚Äôs Co-Founder and Farm Manager, Leah Penniman @leahpenniman, and a performance by world-renowned poet, Soul Fire Farm‚Äôs Program Manager, Naima Penniman @naimainfinity. It will be followed by a Q&A discussion with Naima. If you'd like to take a moment out of your week to listen to our keynote Uprooting Racism, Seeding Sovereignty, join the Emporia University Community on March 25th at 4:00 PM EST. Register at the link in our bio.

items.title: The sun has been parting the clouds, the bright ra‚Ä¶
items.content_html:
@soulfirefarm

The sun has been parting the clouds, the bright rays of warmth touching the ground and melting the snow and ice to reveal the Earth underneath. The ground is beginning to thaw, the microorganisms are awakening from dormancy, and we‚Äôre anticipating the warm weather to come! We can‚Äôt wait to get in our shorts and t-shirts and work under the sunshine again! Featured here are some shots of our farmily donning our Soul Fire Farm T-shirts. Check out the link in our bio to pick one up. Right now, we only have the black T-shirts available!

items.title: We stand in solidarity with our siblings, and we g‚Ä¶
items.content_html:
@soulfirefarm

We stand in solidarity with our siblings, and we grieve along with them and the world through such tragedy and loss. We cannot stand by while such racism and violence occurs and threatens the beautiful communities of those we love. . We must remember them, and find ways to make change amidst the heartbreak, the anger, and grief. Let‚Äôs remember and say the names of the victims that have been confirmed: Xiaojie Tan, Daoyou Feng, Delaunay Ashley Yuan Gonzalez, and Paul Andre Michels. And to the others whose names we do not know yet, our hearts are with you. Reposted from @redcanarysong: We, as we always have, highlight the demands of massage workers. Here are some from massage workers here in NYC.

items.title: Land-dwellers need to know more than just soil car‚Ä¶
items.content_html:
@soulfirefarm

Land-dwellers need to know more than just soil care. From building chicken coops to fixing fences and constructing sheds, there are myriad carpentry projects on the farm. In this virtual basic carpentry workshop, participants will learn about hand and power tool use, layout, measuring, and fastening, with the goal to increase our comfort with the basics of working with wood. Kai and Sean will demonstrate the steps to construct a cold frame to protect outdoor crops and a vertical planter for indoor and/or small-space outdoor growing. Register by heading to the link in our bio!

items.title: I remember when meant pound, not hashtag
items.content_html:
@sohlae

I remember when meant pound, not hashtag. Back when there were landlines and *69? So... I want to call this okay? Make sure you take care of the details: start with room temperature ingredients to create a stable emulsion, cream the butter and sugar until fluff-city, and stop the mixer to scrape down the paddle and the bowl. If you do all that this base vanilla batter can take on anything, from a few extra folds for mix-ins like chopped dates or blueberries, flavors like matcha or lemon zest, or swirls of cocoa and streusel like my black and white variation above! Head over to @food52 to learn my go-to, super tender, unfaltering recipe then take it off-script and make it all your own! Thanks to @emmalaperruque for the expert editing and @gabriellamm @fakattack and @wonbowoo for turning my tried ramblings into a video!

items.title: Want saucy, glossy, sticky, crispy, spicy chicken ‚Ä¶
items.content_html:
@sohlae

Want saucy, glossy, sticky, crispy, spicy chicken wings? Head to the link above to learn my method for brined and roasted chicken wings, then take the recipe off-script to make it your own! For the glassiest skin, be sure to dry brine the wings in salt, sugar, msg, and baking powder for 24 hours A two-temperature roast is key to rendering out all of the fat (flabby wings are not welcome here) then caramelizing the sauce üå∂Make a punchy glaze with acid, heat, and sweet to cut the richness of the chicken Photo by @fakattack

items.title: Do you like history? Do you like food? (Of course,‚Ä¶
items.content_html:
@sohlae

Do you like history? Do you like food? (Of course, you do. That's why you're here!) Then check out my new series on the HISTORY YouTube channel, Ancient Recipes with Sohla every Saturday at noon! Each week, we'll dig up a recipe from the past and see how it does in the now! In this week's episode, I try to bake an ancient pizza recipe on a shieldüõ°Will it pizza??? Tune in to find out! And don‚Äôt miss a new episode of Sunday at 9/8c on The HISTORY Channel!

items.title: Want to braise anything? I
items.content_html:
@sohlae

Want to braise anything? I. Mean. Anything. In the latest installment of Off Script With Sohla on @food52 I‚Äôm teaching you all my golden rules for braising so you can braise whatever the hell you want! Or try my Cashew-Milk Braised Cabbage With Crunchy Chile Oil. It‚Äôs totally vegan, hits you with spice, and the cashew milk transforms into a silky pudding. If you‚Äôre feeling stab-y (who isn‚Äôt these days) take a jab at my Garlic Studded Pork Shoulder With Anchovies and Calabrian Chiles. The pork gets wiggly-tender and moist, perfect hot over polenta or cold in a sando Link above!

items.content_html:
